G.L. c. 186, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, ����������������������������������������������������������, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” is liable for actual and statutory damages.

G.L. c. 218, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, �������������������������������������������������������, and G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 239, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Defendant’s failure was not an isolated incident but continued for more than two months after repeated notice, demonstrating disregard of statutory obligations under G.L. c. 186, �������������������������������������������������������� and G.L. c. 239, ������������������������������������������������������� A, and regulatory standards under 105 C.M.R. 410.480 (requiring doors and locks in good repair).

105 C.M.R. 410.480.proposition: Defendant’s failure was not an isolated incident but continued for more than two months after repeated notice, demonstrating disregard of statutory obligations under G.L. c. 186, §14 and G.L. c. 239, §8A, and regulatory standards under 105 C.M.R. 410.480 (requiring doors and locks in good repair).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The warranty of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely concerns the implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and the timing of rent abatement, not the warranty of quiet enjoyment. Nowhere does the court state that a warranty of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or analyze quiet enjoyment as a doctrine; its discussion is entirely about the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement. Thus, citing this case for a general proposition about quiet enjoyment is inaccurate.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition.” Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 198 (1973). We held that a tenant is entitled to a rent abatement…

Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 326 Mass. 393.proposition: The landlord has an affirmative duty to maintain the premises, including common areas, in a condition fit for habitation and security.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 326 Mass. 393.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about armed robbery and larceny of an automobile; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, habitability, or duties to maintain premises or common areas. The court’s reasoning focuses entirely on evidentiary issues and the sufficiency of proof identifying the defendant as the perpetrator. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for a landlord’s affirmative duty to maintain premises fit for habitation and security.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 326 Mass. 393.relevant_excerpt: The opinion contains no discussion of landlords, tenants, habitability, or duties to maintain premises. It addresses only the facts and law concerning an armed robbery, the theft of an automobile, the admissibility of evidence, and the sufficiency of the evidence to support the convictions.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The landlord has an affirmative duty to maintain the premises, including common areas, in a condition fit for habitation and security.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court explicitly reiterates that every residential landlord has a duty to deliver and maintain the premises in a habitable condition, at least to the level required by the State Sanitary Code, and ties liability to failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions. It further grounds liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 on the landlord’s violation of its duty to maintain sanitary conditions in the tenant’s apartment, which includes common building systems causing flooding, thus supporting an affirmative duty to maintain premises in a condition fit for habitation and tenant security.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt:
“We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition. Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). At a minimum, this warranty imposes on the landlord a duty to keep the dwelling in conformity with the State Sanitary Code.… Further, a landlord that fails to maintain a habitable dwelling for its tenant is liable for resulting personal injuries, at least when the landlord has failed to exercise reasonable care in maintenance.”

“…Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur….”

Foster v. Bartolomeo, 33 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Foster v. Bartolomeo, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 595 (1992)
Foster v. Bartolomeo, 33 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A persistent failure to remedy a serious and known defect that permits intruders and endangers tenants constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment.
Foster v. Bartolomeo, 33 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Botschafter v. Federal Deposit Ins. Corp.
Foster v. Bartolomeo, 33 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns summary judgment on contract, fiduciary duty, emotional distress, defamation, and G.L. c. 93A claims arising from a banking relationship, and then addresses federal jurisdictional limits under FIRREA after the FDIC’s appointment as receiver. It does not involve landlord–tenant relations, building defects, intruders, or interference with quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about failure to remedy a serious defect endangering tenants and interfering with quiet enjoyment.
Foster v. Bartolomeo, 33 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: There is no need for a detailed discussion of the plaintiffs’ claim that there exist genuine issues as to material facts. The Superior Court judge’s allowance of the defendants’ motions for summary judgment was accompanied by a comprehensive memorandum of decision addressing all the counts of the plaintiffs’ complaint. We agree with the reasoning of the Superior Court judge and adopt it as our own.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant’s protection extends to security and peaceful possession.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case interprets the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment to protect tenants against substantial disturbances that render the premises not reasonably habitable, including late-night noise that prevents sleep and causes tenants to vacate. While the opinion does not use the exact phrase "security and peaceful possession," it clearly treats the covenant as safeguarding the tenant’s ability to peacefully occupy and enjoy the premises free from such serious interference. Thus it supports a broad reading of the covenant as extending to peaceful possession and related conditions of habitability.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.

Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.raw_text: Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985)
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.proposition: The covenant’s protection extends to security and peaceful possession.
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions that the landlords violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment (c. 186, § 14), but it does not explain the scope or content of that covenant, nor does it state that its protection specifically extends to security or peaceful possession. The case focuses on habitability defects, emotional distress, and Chapter 93A damages, and treats the quiet enjoyment claim only as overlapping with those theories. Thus it does not provide authority for the particular proposition about the covenant’s protection extending to security and peaceful possession.
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.relevant_excerpt: "The defendants were also found, with respect to the condition of the apartment, to have violated the implied warranty of habitability (see Boston Housing Authy. v. Hemingway, supra) and the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see c. 186, § 14), but recovery was allowed on c. 93A as covering the ground of the other two claims and being the largest of all. See Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 401 (1982)."

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts recognize liability where a landlord’s failure to correct conditions results in fear or loss of use.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case does not frame liability in terms of a tenant’s fear or loss of use alone. Instead, it holds that liability under the Massachusetts quiet enjoyment statute requires at least negligent conduct by the landlord, including notice or reason to know of the condition and failure to take corrective measures. While the opinion cites earlier cases where failure to repair known defects interfered with quiet enjoyment, this decision itself is focused on fault and statutory interpretation, not on recognizing liability merely for fear or loss of use.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts recognize liability where a landlord’s failure to correct conditions results in fear or loss of use.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The court holds that the landlord’s prolonged failure to correct serious sanitary code violations (ventilation and infestation) constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment because the landlord’s omissions impaired the value and character of the premises. While the facts include an actual fire (not mere fear), the court’s reasoning directly recognizes liability based on the landlord’s failure to correct conditions that seriously interfered with the tenants’ tenancy and substantially impaired their use of the unit. Thus, the case supports the principle that liability arises when unremedied conditions significantly impair use/enjoyment of the premises.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. … A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’ … Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem…for over nine years. … On these facts…we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates public policy requiring landlords to provide secure housing.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes statutory and common‑law duties (implied warranty of habitability, covenant of quiet enjoyment, and c. 93A) and applies them to serious code violations, but it does not frame the landlord’s obligations in terms of a broad ‘public policy requiring landlords to provide secure housing.’ The court focuses on habitability, quiet enjoyment, and consumer protection standards, not an articulated public policy of providing secure or safe housing as an independent basis of liability. Thus the case does not support the specific public‑policy proposition stated.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates public policy requiring landlords to provide secure housing.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion involves a landlord’s egregious failure to maintain habitable premises and upholds tenant remedies under the implied warranty of habitability, quiet enjoyment, retaliation, negligence, emotional distress, and Chapter 93A. However, the court does not discuss or frame the landlord’s obligations in terms of a broad public policy requiring landlords to provide ‘secure housing’ as such. Its focus is on statutory and common-law duties regarding habitability and harassment, not an articulated public policy of secure housing, so it does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; … (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents…. On the emotional distress counterclaim, the judge determined that Gonzalez had proved that Haddad's intentional and outrageous conduct had caused her to suffer severe emotional distress… We conclude that, in appropriate circumstances, tenants may recover multiple damages for the intentional infliction of emotional distress under c. 93A.”
